review_title: Our Culture: Commitment. Compassion. Community. Compass.
job_title: Chief People Officer in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Vivent Health has an unyielding commitment to outstanding outcomes for our patients and clients. These outcomes are drawn and driven by the most passionate, talented, dedicated and caring employees, who are called "Champions." Vivent Health is a workplace where every champion is valued and every community is honored. We recently announced many new and enhanced benefits, which are market competitive and impressive. Our culture is evolving. Our trajectory is upward and our potential is unlimited. More to come. Stay tuned......
cons: YOU haven't joined us yet.

pros: Working for Vivent Health was like a dream come true as a pharmacist. I previously worked both retail at a 24-hr store and mail order, so I know this place was the greener side of the grass and could appreciate it. Highlights: - set schedule, no evenings, weekends, or holidays --> amazing work/life balance - non-profit & not for profit --> everything goes back into helping the community - appreciative patients who actually thank you every single day - amazing co-workers who also love what they do - very inclusive environment where everyone can be themselves without judgement - great benefits and very generous PTO policies
cons: The only downside for me and the reason I left Vivent Health is there were no opportunities for growth or advancement. If you are fine having an amazing job and are not looking to further your career, this is the place for you.

pros: The coworkers primarily because you must band together to be able to tolerate this place.
cons: The senior leadership is completely disconnected from the realities of the organization. The issues are covered up to give the sense things are good. Note how some of these reviews are from HR giving 5 stars. This is likely to raise the overall rating to help with the poor retention matters. Also the responses don't acknowledge or accept the opportunities but try to ice over the realities like icing on a burnt cake. New leadership needs to instilled. With a count of 600 or less in the organization, the place has way too many executive level roles. This represents weak leadership and poor processes when you must add more and more executives at the top. For a non profit, this is not a good use of the funds granted.

review_title: Stop sweeping the problems under the rug.
pros: There are some truly wonderful people that work here and embody the mission - they're few and far between, but they can help you survive. The work done to service the communities is admirable and one of the main reasons I chose to work here.
cons: I have never been treated so poorly in a job before - and whenever I asked for help, I was brushed off. I was harrassed, bullied, and demeaned on a regular basis for months with no support. I was treated poorly by my supervisor (to the point that I left this job mentally and emotionally traumatized) and other coworkers and leadership members.

review_title: We're headed down the right path.
job_title: Human Resources Manager in Denver, CO
pros: Innovative home healthcare model that creates a one-stop-shop environment for patients and clients. The convenience and service are second to none. This is why our HIV undetectable rates are the highest in the nation!
cons: We have gone through several mergers in recent years and we're working hard to unify our young family of Champions.

pros: - many employees are stellar, thoughtful, caring people
cons: - services are 100% shaped by what will bring in funding/revenue, not what is right for individuals receiving services; this shady practice seems to line the pockets of the people at the top - constant bragging from leadership about being "nationwide" when, in reality, this org just scoops up successful programs in the middle of the country & then drains them of all their creativity, originality, and community focus - overwhelming amount of meetings where leadership brags about the org, taking away time from actually providing services - lies before supposed "mergers," fail to deliver on promises, & then completely changes + takes over those programs - no room for improvements/development of any ideas, everything must come top-down from the corporate elites in charge - prepare to get reprimanded for doing something as small and harmless as making a fun graphic for a poster -- everything must be their corporate brand, or else - pay is not great, healthcare plan is garbage, they will try to give weird gifts out (like scented playdoh) to pretend they promote "self care" when they can't deliver on benefits/basic decency - they hire demeaning, rude supervisors - pretty sure the CEO did something terrible and got fired... shady!!!

review_title: Amazing, Inclusive, Rewarding place to work!
pros: Amazing benefits Great people Inclusivity and Diversity focused Very flexible A rewarding place to work
cons: I have been at Vivent for almost 3 years and I can not list any cons of working here.

job_title: Case Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Interim CEO is an amazing person who truly cares. Great coworkers who really care about work. Consistent schedule.
cons: Our director is literally never here, seen her in person only handful of times in last year. She can work remote whereas we are expected to take our time. This disconnect greatly impacts morale.

review_title: You Cannot Work Here and Claim to be Ethical
job_title: Community Case Manager in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Agency Mission, decent benefits, Dedicated Colleagues
cons:
The Social Services department, specifically the Case Management department is an absolute nightmare. Case Management is always a tough gig and the leadership there makes it even more difficult through their disorganization and lack of accountability. Lack of staffing forces current staff to over-burden themselves (for the mission!!!) in order to serve clients, but there are more clients than the current staff can manage and clients are being directly harmed because of it. Working the on-call role several days a week and cannot count the number of clients who have not had their rents paid due to an unfit supervisor. When confronted, no accountability is shown. 

The HR department, oh I'm sorry it's called the "Champion Resource Center" is in just as bad a shape. In less than two months, I've been re-assigned to 3 "business partners" because staff continue to quit.

And finally, the CEO has resigned after being investigated for "interactions with champions"; staffed were informed by the interim CEO that we all need to "close ranks" and not discuss this with anyone, but anyone doing this work knows that accountability matters, but instead they are invested in pushing this under the rug so the money can keep flowing!

job_title: Community Case Manager in Kansas City, MO
pros: Phenomenal PTO offerings Great coworkers Amazing clients Truly innovative medical home model
cons: They pay is low. Insultingly low. Calling employees into meeting after meeting after meeting (interrupting their day) to smile and talk about how much you care about them and they are the backbone of the operation, and then pay your C-Suite 10x the Case Managers is a slap in the face. Additionally, you can only use their transition related healthcare bonus if you also have their health insurance. They rolled out tons of benefits in the last six months but most people can't use any of them. At the KC office, there are two managers over social services with WILDLY different approaches. Both have insane turnover rates, but one is worse. She can't leave you alone for a whole hour without feeling compelled to micromanage you. I had not even finished my 90-day training period when I was asked to begin taking on additional duties, for no change in pay. The turnover rate in staff leaves remaining staff routinely covering clients that aren't on their caseload. Clients slip through the gaps as a result. Case loads are way too high, especially when leadership is constantly adding responsibilities and demanding more "quality" interactions. There are a lot of other, somewhat petty complaints I have, but this one isn't petty. Accountability. The number of meetings I had to sit through where the interim CEO gave speech after speech about how Vivent values transparency while telling employees not to say anything to anyone, especially donors or government auditors, about the CEO being under investigation for improper conduct, is staggering.

pros: Good mission and the employees are amazing.
cons: Leadership is a mess. Everyone below VP level is fantastic and there for the right reasons. Outside of that, there's not much structure in place.

pros: Coworkers are great and we have a good relationship with the community.
cons: Just terrible! Great clients, horrible leadership, and CEO. There couldn't be a more significant disconnect between Milwaukee staff and all other locations. For an organization of its size, the pay is terrible. HR seems like a good ol' boys club and spends its time covering up for upper management's unethical behavior.

review_title: Rewarding work with room for Leadership to think outside the box
job_title: HIV Medical Case Manager in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Working with a collaborative health team expanded my knowledge around HIV, Healthcare and overall patient care. Employees that work for agency (and leadership) care about the patients, and you can feel that. The organization is connected to HIV in WI and beyond, and as I was leaving , participation in committees and side projects was expanding. Say yes to opportunities and it'll allow for variation in the monotony that is case management.
cons: upward mobility limited, lack of opportunity to shift in role, due to strict parameters around Case Manager roles. If it not billable they won't work at helping you obtain any type of advancement in your field (Social Worker)

job_title: HIV PrEP Navigator in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
- Flexibility in schedule
- Most of the colleagues are wonderful and support the mission
cons: Management is out of touch. This includes every supervisory position from Directors all the way to the C Suite. They're too focused on expanding instead of fixing the MANY broken existing things. Most employees are overworked, doing the work of multiple people, and far underpaid. They add new executive positions all of the time, many with long titles and no clear understanding of the role. Supervisors are avoidant and struggle with having difficult conversations. And don't even try to get a clear answer on anything... you won't receive it. Turnover is extremely high and often times, there are no new people hired to replace those that leave. This leaves remaining employees with an extra workload.

review_title: Our Culture: Commitment. Compassion. Community. Compass.
job_title: Chief People Officer in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Vivent Health has an unyielding commitment to outstanding outcomes for our patients and clients. These outcomes are drawn and driven by the most passionate, talented, dedicated and caring employees, who are called "Champions." Vivent Health is a workplace where every champion is valued and every community is honored. We recently announced many new and enhanced benefits, which are market competitive and impressive. Our culture is evolving. Our trajectory is upward and our potential is unlimited. More to come. Stay tuned......
cons: YOU haven't joined us yet.

pros: I cannot speak highly enough of the people working in the social services division and the direct service providers at this organization. Many people here have great compassion for the people they serve and for one another. We have been able to do so much good and reach so many in need with the plethora of resources and services we have at our disposal. Supervisors and director in this division are supportive and protective of our teams and work well together on shared goals. Work / life balance is prioritized as well as debriefing / processing to make the work we do sustainable.
cons: I am extremely hopeful for the future of this organization after they have openly addressed some issues with higher ups. I am looking forward to seeing more policy that mirrors how valued employees are and have been excited to see some wonderful benefits added that I have not had in my many years working for other wonderful Milwaukee nonprofits and local government. While I am still seeking to understand why this service based organization is so top heavy, there have been many occasions where feedback is sought out formally and that has been a solid first step for an impressive amount of agile change in a large organization.

review_title: Please read the reviews on this organization
job_title: Social Worker/Case Manager in Milwaukee, WI
pros:
Staff appear to have a heart for their client’s wellness and want to make a difference.
The company offers 401K benefits.
All employees have paid time off for their birthday.
cons:
Low pay.
Poor health benefits.
The supervisors are unprofessional and rude.
The staff turnover rate is unbelievable.

pros: Was once thriving and expanding, the benefits are fairly good, but that's the end of that list.
cons:
Leadership takes a "hands off" approach, leaving little room for vision or strategy, no direction. Departments struggle while leadership doesn't make any changes.

CEO under investigation for unknown reasons and may be let go or asked to leave

job_title: Medical Case Manager in Kansas City, MO
pros: None None None None None
cons: Environment Racism Favorites Pay Benefits No acknowledgment

review_title: Run as fast as you can
job_title: Prevention Specialist in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The front line people care and are about the mission
cons: Hands off leadership that has no idea what’s actually going on in the trenches More concerned about the brand than anything else Poor health insurance

job_title: Case Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Some of the people work hard
cons: Over worked, under paid, never appreciated

pros: Having wonderful patients and colleagues
cons: The entire ASQ building and management. The dental department was the worst

pros: Diversity in thought and work. Supportive leadership (for the most part). Flexibility with parents. Medical home model allows you to work with various different departments. The mission - END HIV. Accountable and great CEO as the leader. Holidays paid off. A genuine effort being made to implement DEIB. Good effort made at acknowledging champions for the good work they do in a company wide setting. Support groups for various populations within the organization.
cons: No real room for growth. Limited training. 3% yearly increase hardly keeps up with inflation. Lots of silos. Remote work not supported. Tuition reimbursement unavailable. Growing very quickly and seemingly losing sight of the very things that drew people to work for the organization (ie: family like atmosphere). Pay is unsustainable especially if you have a family to feed. Turnover rate is still fairly high. Workload for most is overwhelming.

job_title: Case Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Provides good resources for client
cons: Low pay, not great benefits, bad leadership

pros:
Management's always been kind to me
All of my work feels valued, management is willing to listen/take your input on work situations
Very friendly office culture
cons:
Higher ups make sometimes empty promises about improvements being made to the organization/feel out of touch with the rest of the employees
There isn't much room to move up
Benefits could use a revamp

review_title: Run don't walk from this company
pros:
Good co-workers
Clients
Fairly easy organization to get hired into because they always have open positions.
cons:
Management is horrific. Leaders are clueless and just do busy work to remain relevant or to pad their resume for the new position. 
Passive-aggressive culture that is facilitated from top-down. 
Benefits are not great but okay.

pros: Make a difference in the community
cons: Systemic, enterprise-wide communication failures abound and continue to amaze with the depth of their magnitude.

job_title: Supportive Housing Case Manager in Austin, TX
pros: - excellent pay and benefits
cons:
- constant turnover in management 
- poor support from upper management for case managers 
- huge caseloads

pros: Some exceptional coworkers - fulfilling client work.
cons: This was one of the most toxic work environments. In my 2.5 months there, 7 people quit. This company has a track record for poor leadership and toxicity. The case management team was a mean-girl, bullying culture. People there will make you feel like they can be trusted, and then they will turn around and betray your trust and stab you in the back. By the way, most of these positive glass door reviews are planted from within the company. Stay away.

review_title: High Turn Over and Lake of Company Compassion
pros: The people you work with are kind, caring individuals and I adored the ones I worked with.
cons: No one stays longer than a year, there are always open positions. High need case loads not enough support or listening to the needs of employees. Better pay, training, and benefits needed. Since everyone is new there is no one to properly train you when you start.

job_title: Associate Development Director in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Working to provide important resources to people.
cons: No cons worth mentioning in a review.

pros:
LGBTQ & black-friendly workplace
Decent pay
Company match up to 5% for 401(k)
Company automatically deposits money into an HSA for you (if you choose to open one)
Automatically enrolled in 100% annual salary life insurance policy
Company is growing
cons:
BORING office culture (Prevention department)
Super high deductible health plan through UHC

review_title: The best experience I have had as a case manager
job_title: Housing Case Manager in Austin, TX
pros: There is not a lot of micro managing. Your trusted as an adult to do your work.
cons: Health insurance is not great, high co pays and deductibles

pros: Meaningful work, supportive colleagues, office hours/no overtime required
cons: Poor leadership, lack of communication between company, high stress for decent pay

review_title: By far worst place I have ever worked
pros: There were literally no pros to this organization
cons: Leadership here inhibits an extreme power difference. If you think your thoughts, opinions and ideas matter, think again. Expect to come to work feeling anxious, under valued and intimidated because the leadership here is the worst I have ever experienced. They pride themselves on wanted to revamp the organizations culture, prioritizing the employees but they seem to forget how to be good leaders to their own team and treat people nicely. My leader did not know how to connect to people at all. Worst leadership personnel I have yet to experience. Also, worst retention rate I have yet to experience in an organization, but to be honest, I am not surprised with how the organization is ran.

review_title: Great company - Strong commitment to LGBTQIA and Diversity
pros: They are always looking at ways to improve the employee experience and workplace culture. They have a lot of forums for employees to make recommendations and express concerns. The company is growing quickly.
cons: It's a great place to work.

review_title: Decent pay, but bad culture shift after merger
job_title: Program Manager, Non-Profit in Austin, TX
pros: I worked for a Non-Profit that had a merger with Vivent Health. The pros were that Vivent was able to provide more resources that we didn't have prior - better wages, bigger HR and administrative teams, etc.
cons: The merger made the company culture change drastically and feel very corporate. The higher-up folks didn't feel as in touch with what our clients would really want from us.

job_title: HIV Prevention Specialist in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Every day is different. The job is seldom boring.
cons: Job can be stressful at times.

pros: Significant investment in the employees and commitment to diversity, equity, inclusion and belonging. Exciting to be part of a growing organization, with opportunities to collaborate across the nation on cutting-edge programs.
cons: As with any organization that goes through expansion, there are growing pains. However, I am impressed with the steps we have taken to support our growth.

job_title: Psychiatric Nurse Practitioner in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Very nice people work there
cons: The salary is low there

job_title: Dental Assistant in Green Bay, WI
pros: Company truly cares about their patients but that’s it.
cons: Too political. Great place if you wanna hear about all racial and political news 24/7. Expect mandatory 2 hour long meetings required by ALL staff to teach you how to not be racist, expect forced vaccinations, expect your wishes to be accepted and listened to but quickly reversed. Since leaving they won’t even contact me back for my last two paystubs. I gave them over 2 weeks notice and left on good terms. Do not recommend working here after COVID.

pros: Good cause, good team, good people
cons: Disorganization, low morale and turnover

review_title: I'm not sure what to write for a headline
pros: Help vulnerable people, flex schedule
cons: Lower pay compared to private industry

pros: Warm welcoming culture, flexibility with time off, supportive coworkers, growing company that strives for diversity.
cons: Issues with micromanagement, lack of training, supervisors are sometimes not held accountable for lack of staff knowledge.

job_title: HIV Prevention Specialist in Madison, WI
pros: good coworkers, manageable workload, meaningful work, face to face interactions w/ clients
cons: upper management not super responsive to needs of on the ground workers, benefits leave a lot to be desired

pros: Great work environment very friendly
cons: Very stressful with a high burn out rate and no path to promotion

pros: Good salary, team, work, and making an impact
cons: Pay could be better. More opportunities for growth

pros: The technology is really great and up to date.  The people here are generally nice and can hold conversation.
cons: Coincidentally all of these recent good reviews are coming out during inner turmoil within the company, which causes me to believe they aren't real.  Morale and pay are low and people are sick of it.  Senior Leadership will do whatever they can to pay you as little as possible while having no problem spending thousands of dollars on tables, chairs, office plants, desks, etc. for their own offices.  Mergers are going to become more and more common with no additional staff to assist with the added workload.  This leads to needing to spend extra hours working on your normal job because work hours were spent dealing with merger business.

pros: The company really does help patients live better lives.  Staff support each other.  There are plenty of ways that the company can make an even bigger difference in the lives of people with HIV, if staff had more time to focus on each individual patient.
cons: Too focused on growth.  Let’s give everyone amazing care before expanding more.  The company sets very ambitious goals that are often unattainable.  Staff are overworked and demoralized.  Company does not encourage career growth and  development so turnover is higher than it needs to be.  This also negatively impacts the experience that patients have.

review_title: Undervalued and Unappreciated. Do not recommend for employment
job_title: Case Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Assisting the HIV community, coworkers are dedicated and go above and beyond for clients
cons: Low pay, no flexibility, terrible health insurance benefits, leadership is a joke.

pros: Great environment, great people, great benefits. I miss working there and everyone with whom I worked!
cons: Sometimes the micromanagement (from top management) of some job aspects seemed arbitrary and unfair. Some decisions seemed to directly contradict everyone's shared mission of providing compassionate care in the most efficient way possible. I understand some of this has been improved within the past couple of years, however.

review_title: Solid company; Management improving but needs more time
pros: The staff are very energetic, and committed to the cause.  Benefits are good, and the company is one of the top performers in it's field.  Always new projects and initiatives starting, and the CEO is always looking forward.  Benefits are good; probably better than average for nonprofits.
cons: There is considerable burnout as staff are pushed to really produce and work long hours.  Managers need some improvement, as many of the issues they face relate back to staff which were not properly managed.  This is further complicated by a lack of personnel policies. While they have an HR dept, it is very dysfunctional.

pros: I've been working with Vivent since the beginning of 2020, and have been thoroughly impressed with their operations. Their goals are truly client driven, and they have grown increasingly attentive to employee needs and concerns through the COVID-19 pandemic. They have also incorporated intentional training around systemic racism and improving workplace culture, which has been well thought out. Compensation is very appropriate, and the health insurance is very fair and comprehensive.
cons: The organization may be a little top heavy, and is expanding quickly to other states/regions. While it has not grown too big yet, there are some worries that the rate of expansion might leave some locations with less attention.

pros: The people are this company are wonderfully dedicated to ending HIV through a medical home model. In house they offer prevention services, a food pantry, medical, dental, and behavioral health services and individual case management.
cons: Low salaries and not a lot of upward mobility.

review_title: Incredible Organization with a true vision of offering help and prevention - they save lives.
pros: Opportunities to learn, develop and expand your own skills and new skills. All levels of Management are approachable.  Your ideas are heard and discussed and possibly explored, sometimes put into action.
cons: I have no complaints. Even as they grow the vision of the organization is not lost.

pros: The people that work with you are very nice.
cons: Upper management is full of themselves and takes it out on their underlings.

review_title: Great people, great place to work.
pros: Incredible personal/professional growth that I will use throughout my career.  Great office culture with a supportive environment.
cons: salaries need to be re-evaluated, cubicle atmosphere and sometimes boring work.

pros: The pantry team is a wonderful group of people. Hours are flexible and laid back environment.
cons: Outsourcing foods to serve and the constant volume change of clients

pros: Lovely people ,vision and work environment
cons: Low pay while the executive earns almost 10 times

pros: People you work with, knowing you are helping people
cons: Emotionally taxing, low pay, fast employee burnout

pros: Communication is good, feel valued
cons: I don't feel there are any cons.

pros: Patient care, coworkers, benefits and pay
cons: Does not apply at all
